content:
Hi all :wave:, I've officially fallen in love with topos theory and I have a vague question (maybe more of a reference request) about the construction of subobject classifiers. Please bear with me as I wave my hands. Here's the question:

  • The way one constructs subobject classifiers in (co)pre-sheaf categories is just beautiful: it's done in terms of sieves on any object. Is there an analogue of this construction in any elementary topos? By this I mean, is there a formulaic construction which will always yield the definition of a subobject classifier in a category $\mathsf{C}$ whenever subobject classifiers exists in $\mathsf{C}$?
as it is stated, the question admits "yes" as answer, but I think it's not what you wanted to ask

Maybe you want to ask: there's a particularly elegant way to prove that categories of the form SetCoSet^{C^o}SetCo have a subobject classifier. Is there a similar way to prove that elementary toposes [of the form...?] have a subobject classifier?
hmm, probably, I guess I'm asking if there's something like a formula for subobject classifiers in the same way as there's a formula for Kan extensions :man_shrugging:
ah, I understand (probably) what you want. Say you have a category and you know it has a subobject classifier; is there a way to compute it?
If yes, I've never seen one besides the one for Grothendieck toposes. For elementary toposes.. maybe the keyword is something something Lawvere-Tierney topologies?
At a very naive level, a subobject classifier is a representing object for the subobject functor, which means a terminal object in its category of elements
so whatever recipe you have to find the terminal object of ∫SubC\int Sub_C∫SubC​ gives CCC a subobject classifier

Am I hallucinating, or is the terminal object of a category the colimit of the 'full diagram': the diagram consisting of all objects and morphisms in the category?

For example, this is true for a poset.

fosco said:

ah, I understand (probably) what you want. Say you have a category and you know it has a subobject classifier; is there a way to compute it?

Yes, this is exactly it! :thank_you:

John Baez said:

Am I hallucinating, or is the terminal object of a category the colimit of the 'full diagram': the diagram consisting of all objects and morphisms in the category?

this sounds correct to me!
Thanks a lot for the answers, I'll ponder it a bit!

Okay, thanks. So then I guess you can get get the subobject classifier of C\mathsf{C}C, if it exists, using the philosophy that 1↪TΩ1 \xhookrightarrow{T} \Omega1T​Ω is the 'walking subobject' or 'mother of all subobjects': any subobject of any object XXX is obtained via pullback from some morphism X→ΩX \to \OmegaX→Ω.

So, this makes me want to build it as a colimit of a diagram whose objects are all possible object/subobject pairs A↪BA \hookrightarrow BA↪B in C\mathsf{C}C, and whose arrows are all maps between these. Or something like that.

Even if I'm right this is a thoroughly impractical method, but when the colimit exists it should be a terminal object in some category of object-subobject pairs, and this should match Fosco's description.

I'm a bit fuzzy about a lot of the details here, but to the extent I understand them, all I'm doing it dramatizing what Fosco said, using the philosophy that the subobject classifier is the "walking subobject" (i.e. it's an object, and a subobject of that, which is universal among such object-subobject pairs).

It's late evening for me, but I think these two descriptions we gave are equivalent and equally tautological; a terminal object of CCC exists iff the identity functor has a colimit; this poses the problem of non-existence of a general formula to compute a colimit of a diagram that "CCC recognizes as large"
it's a nice observation anyway, that one can just reduce to Ω≅colim(id∫Sub)\Omega \cong colim(id_{\int Sub})Ω≅colim(id∫Sub​) (woah, that's a lot of nested notation)
let's wait for the true topos theorists (=not me)
Is it possible to "present" an elementary topos as a presheaf topos?
Not always! For example: the category of finite sets is an elementary topos, but not a presheaf topos.
Any presheaf topos (or more generally any [[Grothendieck topos]]) has all small colimits and limits, while an elementary topos need only have finite ones.
[Forgive the late night blasphemy]: I would then say it's not true that every elementary topos arises as a left exact localization of FinCoFin^{C^o}FinCo?
(for a small C)
morally, C should be the subcategory of compact objects, and I don't see why the elementary topos axioms make it a generator.
also true or false that every category of the form FinCoFin^{C^o}FinCo is a fairly canonical example of an elementary topos? I must admit I have never thought about this banality and I feel ashamed!
I can't answer your sophisticated question but what I call FinSetCop\mathsf{FinSet}^{\mathsf{C}^{\textrm{op}}}FinSetCop is indeed an elementary topos. (I seem to use more letters than you.)

I guess XCop\mathsf{X}^{\mathsf{C}^{\textrm{op}}}XCop is an elementary topos whenever X\mathsf{X}X is the category of all sets whose cardinality is less than some [[inaccessible cardinal]]. The countably infinite cardinal ω0\omega_0ω0​ would count as an inaccessible cardinal except some jerk stuck a clause into the definition explicitly excluding it.

An elementary topos need not have any generator, so you definitely can’t restrict to CCC small, and you definitely can’t restrict to presheaves valued only in finite sets. A locally small cocomplete topos is pretty close to the same as a lex total category, ie a left exact localization of the category of presheaves of small sets on some locally small category (ie itself) though.

As to your original question, @Benjamin Merlin Bumpus (he/him), I think the answer is mostly no; this construction is so nice because CCC-presheaves have CCC as a dense small generator. If CCC is a site you get something worse but still something, but in general with no generator I see little hope of anything that feels nontrivially analogous. I’m not super confident in this claim except insofar as arbitrary toposes are pretty weird so I have priors on things being weird.
So in an elementary topos there is no way to compute Ω\OmegaΩ, so to speak.
I’m saying I guess there’s no general nontrivial way to do so, yeah.

Benjamin Merlin Bumpus (he/him) said:

Hi all :wave:, I've officially fallen in love with topos theory

Welcome!

John Baez said:

I can't answer your sophisticated question but what I call FinSetCop\mathsf{FinSet}^{\mathsf{C}^{\textrm{op}}}FinSetCop is indeed an elementary topos. (I seem to use more letters than you.)

Are you sure? Think about what happens for a poset PPP of infinite depth, or more specifically a poset in which some element xxx has infinitely many elements below it, such as the terminal object in the ordinal ω+1\omega + 1ω+1. We have a Yoneda embedding P→FinSetPopP \to \mathsf{FinSet}^{P^{\mathrm{op}}}P→FinSetPop, since PPP is locally finite (beware that this is not necessarily the free finite cocompletion of PPP, as Kevin pointed out in another topic). Moreover, the [[Yoneda lemma]] holds: elements of F(x)F(x)F(x) are in bijection with natural transformations yx⇒Fy_x \Rightarrow Fyx​⇒F (you can inspect the proof and see that it applies as soon as the representable presheaf exists, since it only relies on the naturality condition), and hence the preservation of limits by the Yoneda embedding holds, whence yxy_xyx​ has infinitely many subobjects -- in a poset, all morphisms are monomorphisms.
So if the subobject functor were represented by some object Ω\OmegaΩ, we would have Ω(x)\Omega(x)Ω(x) being infinite (corresponding to yxy_xyx​ having infinitely many subobjects), which is not allowed since our presheaves have to take values in finite sets!

In summary, for FinSetCop\mathsf{FinSet}^{\mathcal{C}^{\mathrm{op}}}FinSetCop to be a topos when C\mathcal{C}C has finite homsets, it is necessary for C\mathcal{C}C to also be 'finitely powered'. I am a little curious if:

  1. this is also sufficient (I think it isn't: we can certainly take finite colimits of representables, so if there are infinitely many finitely generated sieves over an object, we hit the same problem!)
  2. you can avoid this condition when C\mathcal{C}C has larger homsets (I think not).
    I think the latter may be a distraction from @Benjamin Merlin Bumpus (he/him) 's original question, but the former should be a little informative.

Are you sure?

Rapidly getting less so.... :sweat_smile:
Thanks for disabusing me of that notion, and then going the extra mile to find extra conditions to fix my guess.

I guess this generalization for larger cardinalities also needs to be fixed, at least when C\mathsf{C}C has more than κ\kappaκ objects (or morphisms):

John Baez said:

I guess XCop\mathsf{X}^{\mathsf{C}^{\textrm{op}}}XCop is an elementary topos whenever X\mathsf{X}X is the category of all sets whose cardinality is less than some [[inaccessible cardinal]] κ\kappaκ.

Yeah I think this is basically because ω+1\omega + 1ω+1 is a "large category" from the perspective of FinSet\mathsf{FinSet}FinSet, and that for similar reasons SetCop\mathsf{Set}^{\mathcal{C}^\mathsf{op}}SetCop isn't in general a topos when C\mathcal{C}C is large ... so the same should happen for various inaccessible cardinals.

If anyone has access to Sketches of an Elephant, check out Example A2.1.5: if CCC is a category all of whose slice categories are essentially small, then SetCop\mathrm{Set}^{C^{\mathrm{op}}}SetCop is an elementary topos.

Ah, so FinSetωop\mathsf{FinSet}^{\omega^\mathsf{op}}FinSetωop is kind of a "scaled down" version of that, and ω+1\omega + 1ω+1 fails because it has a terminal object and the slice over that is as large as the original category.
Having read Elephant A2.1.5, plus the above, it seems like the "if" can be strengthened to "iff" ... am I dreaming?

So you'd need to argue that if every representable presheaf has only a small number of subobjects, then all slice categories are essentially small. That's not obvious to me; a priori it seems like there could be other "accidental" ways for representables to have small subobject lattices. Is there an argument for it contained somewhere in this thread?

It seems more obvious to me when you look at the exponential objects than the subobject classifier. Or at least it did--I'm no longer sure I understand the argument for why exponentials turn out as small presheaves in the first place! (for the A2.1.5 case, not the C\mathcal{C}C small case.)
Maybe it's easier to understand why power objects turn out small.
Thanks everyone for the comments; I’ve learned a lot from reading all of this!

btw, old fql can compute sub-object classifiers for the category of copresheaves on certain finitely presented categories. Here's a picture of the subobject classifier for the category of copreshaves on the category with a single generating arrow f:a->b.
Screenshot-2024-09-02-at-12.42.57PM.png

Ryan Wisnesky said:

btw, old fql can compute sub-object classifiers for the category of copresheaves on certain finitely presented categories. Here's a picture of the subobject classifier for the category of copreshaves on the category with a single generating arrow f:a->b.
Screenshot-2024-09-02-at-12.42.57PM.png

that seems very cool but i wouldn't know how to interpret this screenshot. would you mind adding an explanation for how to read it?

The copresheaf Ω:C→Set\Omega : C \to \text{Set}Ω:C→Set is described in the two tables aaa and bbb.

Table aaa represents the set Ω(a)\Omega(a)Ω(a) lying over aaa. Similarly for table bbb.
You see a column fff in table aaa, containing ids of rows from table bbb (aka a foreign key if you are familiar with relational database). This column encodes the function Ω(f):Ω(a)→Ω(b)\Omega(f) : \Omega(a) \to \Omega(b)Ω(f):Ω(a)→Ω(b).

Explicitly, Ω(a)={6,7,8}\Omega(a) = \{6, 7, 8\}Ω(a)={6,7,8} and Ω(b)={9,10}\Omega(b) = \{9, 10\}Ω(b)={9,10}. The function Ω(f)\Omega(f)Ω(f) is

Ω(f):Ω(a)→Ω(b)6,8↦107↦9\begin{align*} \Omega(f): \Omega(a) &\to \Omega(b) \\ 6, 8 &\mapsto 10 \\ 7 &\mapsto 9 \\ \end{align*}Ω(f):Ω(a)6,87​→Ω(b)↦10↦9​

(However, I have to think about it a bit more to see why this is the subobject classifier)

I'm expecting Ω(a)=2 \Omega(a) = 2 Ω(a)=2 and Ω(b)=1 \Omega(b) = 1 Ω(b)=1 though
Edit: Oops, forgot the empty cosieves, my bad. that matches up then!

fosco said:

ah, I understand (probably) what you want. Say you have a category and you know it has a subobject classifier; is there a way to compute it?

@fosco there are definite methods to calculate subobject classifiers (of both localic and cohesive categories), which I learned from Professor F. William Lawvere and used to calculate subobject classifiers of various categories:
Truth and the terminal object
Structure and Logic of Conceptual Mind
Objective Logic of Consciousness
Functorial Semantics for the Advancement of the Science of Cognition
Subobject Classifier Algorithm
I'll be back in a little while to elaborate and address any questions you may have, and to learn about your corrections of any mistakes I might have made in the above. I'll also look for any additional calculations of truth value objects in categories not included in the above manuscripts.

John Baez said:

So, this makes me want to build it as a colimit of a diagram whose objects are all possible object/subobject pairs A↪BA \hookrightarrow BA↪B in C\mathsf{C}C, and whose arrows are all maps between these. Or something like that.

I have nothing intelligent to add to the discussion on subobject classifiers, only to say that (depending on what you mean by morphism of monomorphisms) this construction is very similar to/identical to the construction of the local state classifier due to @Ryuya Hora (see Definition 3.5 here).

Joshua Wrigley said:

this construction is very similar to/identical to the construction of the local state classifier due to Ryuya Hora (see Definition 3.5 here).

Thank you for mentioning me! As you pointed out, a local state classifier Ξ=colim(Emono→E)\Xi=\mathrm{colim}(E_{\textrm{mono}}\to E)Ξ=colim(Emono​→E), defined as the colimit of all monomorphisms, looks similar to John Baez's description. Actually, there is a substantial connection, but maybe in a dual way from what one would expect: the local state classifier coincides with the colimit of all quotient objects.

ΩE=colim(∫Sub→E)\Omega_E = \mathrm{colim} \left(\int \mathrm{Sub} \to E \right)ΩE​=colim(∫Sub→E)

ΞE=colim(∫Quo→E)\Xi_E =\mathrm{colim} \left(\int \mathrm{Quo} \to E\right)ΞE​=colim(∫Quo→E)

Although there are a lot of interesting things around here, I refrain from digressing too much.

James Deikun said:

Having read Elephant A2.1.5, plus the above, it seems like the "if" can be strengthened to "iff" ... am I dreaming?

This has been my favorite puzzle for several years, and I have been spending so much (maybe too much) time thinking about this. I am glad to see it here. One important remark is that there are two different questions around here:

  1. Is FinSetC\mathrm{FinSet}^CFinSetC an elementary topos?
  2. Is FinSetC\mathrm{FinSet}^CFinSetC an elementary topos such that the embedding FinSetC↪SetC\mathrm{FinSet}^C\hookrightarrow \mathrm{Set}^CFinSetC↪SetC preserves the structure of elementary topoi?

(I scaled down the question from Set\mathrm{Set}Set to FinSet\mathrm{FinSet}FinSet.)
The difference is exemplified by FinSetQ≅FinSet\mathrm{FinSet}^\mathbb{Q}\cong \mathrm{FinSet}FinSetQ≅FinSet.
Maybe what we are really interested in is the latter question rather than the former.

(By the way, the former question is also interesting as a puzzle. It might be fun to prove the following paradoxical fact:

  • While FinSetN\mathrm{FinSet}^\mathbb{N}FinSetN is not a topos,
  • FinSetR≥\mathrm{FinSet}^\mathbb{R_{\geq}}FinSetR≥​ is a topos in a disappointing way!

Here, N,R≥\mathbb{N}, \mathbb{R}_{\geq}N,R≥​ are regarded as monoids.)
